title: British ISIS widow Sally Jones 'among Jihadi brides plotting terror attack return to UK'
text:
News British ISIS widow Sally Jones 'among Jihadi brides plotting terror attack return to UK' Information handed to Prime Minister Theresa May claims women born in Britain and recruited by the terror group could wreak havoc if ISIS is defeated abroad Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Muslim convert Sally Jones allegedly training women for Jihad Share this video   Thank you for subscribing!   
A top secret dossier compiled by intelligence agencies have raised fears bloodthirsty 'Jihadi brides' like Sally Jones will pose a huge threat to the security of the UK once they return from Syria. 
Information handed to Prime Minister Theresa May claims women born in Britain and recruited by the terror group - including former punk rocker Jones - could wreak havoc if ISIS is defeated abroad. 
Jones, 47, has remained at large since her husband, Islamic State recruit Junaid Hussain, was killed in a US drone strike in 2015. 
The intelligence document, seen by the Mail on Sunday, reveals women and children are more likely to be used to carry out terrorist attacks in the West as ISIS loses control of its strongholds in Raqqa and Mosul. 
It is feared female European Jihadis will make their way back home in what is being dubbed the ‘Raqqa scatter’, to carry out terror attacks if they can escape prosecution, wrote the Birmingham Mail . Read More Aid convoy that included murdered ISIS hostage Alan Henning was 'used to smuggle cash to extremists' Experts say women recruited by the terror group - including Jones (pictured) - could wreak havoc if ISIS is defeated abroad 
More than 850 British people have reportedly travelled to Syria and Iraq, with most going to join ISIS. Half of those are believed to have already returned to their home countries. 
According to the Mail on Sunday, the report states: “The threat women pose is likely to be greater than the available intelligence allows us to assess.’ The intelligence document reveals women and children are more likely to be used to carry out terrorist attacks in the West 
The document states around 80 women and 90 British-born children are still in Syria, with the report warning they could use false identities to return to the UK. 
Nikita Malik, an ISIS expert from think-tank the Quilliam Foundation, said: “We have seen child soldiers in other theatres of war, but nothing like under ISIS, who brainwash children through their schools.” Sally Jones plays in her punk band before she joined the terror group (Photo: YouTube) Jones, 47, has remained at large since her husband, Islamic State recruit Junaid Hussain (pictured), was killed in a US drone strike in 2015 (Photo: Birmingham Mail) 
In February 2016, mum Tareena Shakil, from Birmingham, was jailed for six years at Birmingham Crown Court. 
She became the first British woman to be found guilty of joining the Islamic State terror group after she fled to Syria with her toddler son. Read More 'Islamic State' suicide bomber’s corpse explodes inside hospital morgue refrigerator 
Shakil, 28, told her family she was going to Turkey on a beach holiday - but secretly fled across the border to Syria and was taken to the capital of the terrorist caliphate. In February 2016, mum Tareena Shakil, from Birmingham, was jailed for six years at Birmingham Crown Court (Photo: PA) Tareena Shakil as she poses for a custody photograph without a head scarf (Photo: AFP) 
The jury heard Shakil, of Beechfield Road, said she wished to become a “martyr” but also claimed she only travelled to Syria to live under sharia law when she left the UK in October 2014. 
Jones, originally from Kent, became known as the White Widow after the death of computer hacker Hussain. 
She is reportedly leader of the secret Anwar al-Awlaki battalion's female wing - where she is said to be responsible for training European terror recruit females. 
Jones has been prolific with ISIS propaganda on Twitter, where she has gone under the name of Umm Hussain al-Britani. Like us on Facebook
